title: Welcome To My Blog
text:
This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesn’t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

text:

title: My name is Tanya Michelle Justin
text:
This is a ridiculous thing I’m writing in Arvinds class.



library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggformula)

Loading required package: scales

Attaching package: 'scales'

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    discard

The following object is masked from 'package:readr':

    col_factor

Loading required package: ggridges

New to ggformula?  Try the tutorials: 
    learnr::run_tutorial("introduction", package = "ggformula")
    learnr::run_tutorial("refining", package = "ggformula")

library(babynames)


babynames

# A tibble: 1,924,665 × 5
    year sex   name          n   prop
   <dbl> <chr> <chr>     <int>  <dbl>

10  1880 F     Sarah      1288 0.0132

babynames %>% filter(name=="Tanya")

    year sex   name      n       prop
   <dbl> <chr> <chr> <int>      <dbl>
 1  1914 F     Tanya    10 0.0000126 
 2  1915 F     Tanya     6 0.00000586
 3  1916 F     Tanya     6 0.00000553

10  1925 F     Tanya     9 0.00000713
# ℹ 124 more rows



babynames %>% filter(name=="Tanya") %>% 
  gf_line(n~year)








lol what a common name.

title: 27th september: Summarising Data
text:
Introduction
Today we are learning to summarize data so we can get relevant data that is significant to us.

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.3     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.2     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(mosaic)

Registered S3 method overwritten by 'mosaic':
  method                           from   
  fortify.SpatialPolygonsDataFrame ggplot2

The 'mosaic' package masks several functions from core packages in order to add 
additional features.  The original behavior of these functions should not be affected by this.

Attaching package: 'mosaic'

The following object is masked from 'package:Matrix':

    mean

The following objects are masked from 'package:dplyr':

    count, do, tally

The following object is masked from 'package:purrr':

    quantile, sd, t.test, var

    max, mean, min, prod, range, sample, sum

library(knitr)
library(kableExtra)


Attaching package: 'kableExtra'

The following object is masked from 'package:dplyr':

    group_rows

library(babynames)

Here we are taking a data set called mpg and and viewing the first 10 columns:

mpg %>% 
  head(10)

Since, the computer R studio doesn’t recognize that certain variables are Ordinal. Here is a code that converts the data to Ordinal (factor).

you can see that <int> has changed to <fct>


mpg_modified <- mpg %>%
  dplyr::mutate(
    cyl = as_factor(cyl),
    fl = as_factor(fl),
    drv = as_factor(drv),
    class = as_factor(class),
    trans = as_factor(trans)
  )
glimpse(mpg_modified)

Playing Around!!
I imported the library baby names and will try summarizing it.

glimpse(babynames)

Now I will take sex and factor it because its an Ordinal data that has two levels.

You can see that <char> has changed to <fct>


babynames_modified <- babynames %>% 
  dplyr::mutate(
    sex= as.factor(sex)
  )
glimpse(babynames_modified)
